The results presented identify the first genetic lesion associated with DLCL , the most clinically relevant form of NHL .

Although no proof yet exists of a role for these lesions in DLCL pathogenesis , the feature of the <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene product , its specific pattern of expression in B cells , and the clustering of lesions disrupting its regulatory domain strongly suggest that deregulation of <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression may contribute to DLCL development .

A more precise definition of the role of <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in normal and neoplastic B-cell development is the goal of ongoing study of transgenic mice engineered either to express <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> under heterologous promoters or lacking <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> function due to targeted deletions .
In addition to contributing to the understanding of DLCL pathogenesis , the identification of <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> lesions may have relevant clinical implications .
DLCL represent a heterogeneous group of neoplasms which are treated homogeneously despite the fact that only 50 % of patients experience long-term disease-free survival ( Schneider et al . 1990 ) .

The fact that <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> rearrangements identify biologically and clinically distinct subsets of DLCL suggests that these lesions may be useful as markers in selection of differential therapeutic strategies based on different risk groups .
Furthermore , the <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> rearrangements can be used to identify and monitor the malignant clone with sensitive PCR-based techniques .

Since clinical remission has been observed in a significant fraction of DLCL cases , these markers may serve as critical tools for sensitive monitoring of minimal residual disease and early diagnosis of relapse ( Gribben et al . 1993 ) .
